fields.headline: Spending through Cottage roof
fields.bodyText: Fulham suffered a £23.3m loss last year, the biggest in British football history, after splashing out to get into the Premiership. The club's wage bill soared and net debts increased to £61.7m in the year to June 30 2001. That predated Jean Tigana's £36m summer spending. Staff costs, including players' wages, increased to £19.3m, £8m higher than the previous year, when Fulham made a £13.9m loss. These latest losses incurred by Mohamed Al Fayed's club eclipse Newcastle's £18.9m deficit in 2000. However, Fulham expect significant financial benefits from being in the Premiership, not least television income, and do not sound worried. "To build a club for the future involves a substantial financial commitment," said their financial director Andy Ambler. · You've read the piece, now have your say.
